body: Your CUDA version is 11 and none of the TF versions are compatible with that (see [here](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/source#tested_build_configurations)). Do you also get CUDA 11 when you run `nvcc --version`? In certain situations `nvidia-smi` and `nvcc --version` can have different outputs (see [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53422407/different-cuda-versions-shown-by-nvcc-and-nvidia-smi)). In any case, it could be related to your CUDA version and as long as you don't delete your labeled-frames folder you won't need to label again!

Do you recommend downgrading to CUDA 9/10 within the environment I'm using?
Or conda wide? I downloaded the cudatoolskit to my env (conda install -c
anaconda cudatoolkit==9.0) but I'm still running into the same problem.

> Your CUDA version is 11 and none of the TF versions are compatible with
> that (see here
> <https://www.tensorflow.org/install/source#tested_build_configurations>).
> Do you also get CUDA 11 when you run nvcc --version? In certain
> situations nvidia-smi and nvcc --version can have different outputs (see

> In any case, it could be related to your CUDA version and as long as you

>> Resource exhausted: OOM when allocating tensor 

This means a few things: 

(1) your images are too large; did you use cropandlabel before creating the training dataset?

https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/745
https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/740
https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/22
documented extensively here: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/issues/791

https://forum.image.sc/t/resource-exhausted-error-oom-when-allocating-tensor/22216/2

(2) mismatch of TF, CUDA, etc -here, you should run the testsript.py (if you are current with the main repo; to use the latest code follow this: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/wiki/How-to-use-the-latest-GitHub-code, then this video for testing!: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IOWtKn3l33s
